instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_TACH: What is SMC_FAN_0_TACH? SMC_FAN_0_TACH is a signal that comes from the SMC that controls fan speed. Often when the fan is spinning too fast it is because the user has ripped off a resistor that this signal goes through before the signal reaches the fan while unplugging the fan..
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_CTL: What is SMC_FAN_0_CTL? SMC_FAN_0_CTL is a line between the SMC and the fan that controls fan speed that is frequently disturbed when someone inexperienced knocks resistors in the area off with their fingernail or screwdriver when unplugging the fan. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message:
Clean machine, no signs of liquid, boots up does not feel "jerky" when booting

From the moment the power button is pressed the fan runs 100%.

Tried Known good Battery, SSD, DC in, Dc in flex, Track pad, track pad flex and two different fans.

EFI Asd tells me : "Motor is running slower than it should" passes all other test. Can't get the OS ASD to load up.


<TRANSISTOR>Q5660</TRANSISTOR>
pin 1 3.3v
pin 2 3.3v
pin 3 4.58v

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5660</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5665</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5660</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5661</RESISTOR> no change. Tested continuity in all this area and seems fine.

Damaged trace to SMC ? Would be grateful of any hints!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message: SMC is not seeing the tacho signal from the fan. Check <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_TACH</SIGNAL> and the resistors. Also diode mode on this line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message:
Thank you duke.

Diode mode to ground for <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_TACH</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5665</RESISTOR> pin 1) 0.56v

Voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_TACH</SIGNAL> when turned on is 3.146v (both at probe point near SMC and on <RESISTOR>R5665</RESISTOR> pin 1)

I replaced <RESISTOR>R5565</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5660</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5661</RESISTOR> again checked continuity round this area, no change.

Thanks for any help you might give!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message: Tach signal can be viewed on a scope, see if there are pulses there. Also check diode mode on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message:
Thank you Duke. It has continuous regular pulses on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_TACH</SIGNAL>.
Diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_O_CTL</SIGNAL> is 0.550v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan runs 100% immediately
threads.message: That does all seem fine then. SMC seems like the next suspect if you are sure that the fan and connector makes good contact.
